The issue is that it's very hard to get the vast community tooling online for a new network.

author: robocopsgonemad
content: one of the reasons I liked Option 4 (whole new network) is, yes, it is more work, but it also parallelizes better and requires less coordination. Users take on more work than operators/coredevs

author: jakubgs
content: Is there some fool-proof way of knowing if a node pair is good? Because I have seen BN/El pairs work fine for hours and then they desync

author: nflaig
content: you can't copy-paste the state, we don't support restarting the node from unfinalized yet although we have a experimental branch for that already which in theory "should work", see https://github.com/ChainSafe/lodestar/pull/7509

author: barnabasbusa
content: if you can get this to work by next week we are happy to get some big chungus machines rolling with lodestar

author: barnabasbusa
content: then we can probably point ~1M validators to them, so we can get the health back

author: nflaig
content: `ethpandaops/lodestar:start_from_local_ws_state-34a12f7` if you feel like giving it a try, the idea is that we are also able to boot up from a checkpoint state file you would either download from a checkpoint sync url or remote beacon node to be instantly syced to head... this is a bit unsafe if you decide to pick the wrong chain... so really it's a bit tricky and requires social coordination... we still think the only safe way is to sync from last finalized but that's of course really painful right now

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: We planned to restart operating today those keys, however we still found a few more memory issues. Still working on itâ€¦

author: kamil_chodola
content: Is there a chance to have a backup node and move at least part of hose keys there? So You can keep on working on issues while giving a bit better health for network?

author: arnetheduck
content: freeform thought: maybe just 8 aggregates per block is on the low end of things? cc <@425572898787426305>  what that number fails to capture, from re-reading the EIP, is network instability effects where there are _many_ different block votes that unite around a source/target

author: arnetheduck
content: holesky would be a lot less sensitive to missed blocks if more variety in attestation specifics could be included

author: arnetheduck
content: ie increase it to 16 and we can both include _older_ attestations _and_ recent attestations for different head blocks which still are useful as source/target votes

author: arnetheduck
content: I don't really remember the rationale of keeping it _that_ low

author: nflaig
content: do you have metrics on nimbus side to suggest this is a issue, looking at our missed attestations, the ones that make it into an aggregate are essentially always included on-chain at this point in time, although I also don't see a reason why we wouldn't bump this number to 16 just to be safe, any major downsides?

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: Sure, those keys will be used very soon one way or another.
